posts.cooked: Hi all My team are build a big sistem to the robot and we’ll need to extend the CAN wiring. Are there some rule to the maximum allowed extension?

link_counts.title: What is the max length the can bus can be?

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked:
I’m sure you have nothing to worry about.

Problem: I am building a CAN bus and I need to know the maximum length of the CAN Bus, or the maximum distance between end Nodes. Additionally, what is the maximum distance that any Node can be from the main CAN bus? Lastly, what values should I use...

The shortest maximum length (corresponding to the highest transmission rate) is 40m (130 ft). If your CANbus is anywhere close to 130 feet long, I would be shocked.

link_counts.title: Maximum Cable Length For a CAN Bus

posts.cooked:
On a related but slightly different subject, but not sure if it deserves its own thread.

Has anyone had any issues running long CAN runs in the same energy chain as power wires?  I would rather not do multiple energy chains, but I have often heard you should keep your signal wires away from power wires if possible.
We’ve always had our power and signal wires touching because of our cable management and it’s been fine. Do you know why those people would say that because I’d be interested as to why you shouldn’t.

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked: That’s a far bigger concern for AC circuits.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
CAN wires are twisted (and sometimes shielded) to reduce the impact of this kind of EMI.

I’ve never had an issue in FRC or otherwise running twisted CAN wires next to power wires, even for extended lengths like elevator/arm umbilical cords.

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked:
chadr03:

I have often heard you should keep your signal wires away from power wires if possible.

Using twisted wire pairs for the CANbus is the best option. As @JamesCH95 indicated, this will reduce the susceptibility to EMI from nearby power wires. DC circuits generally would not produce excessive amounts of EMI between the battery and the motor controller. The motor wires for brushless motors might produce a bit more EMI given the way the power is commutated by the motor controller, but even there the current going out one wire and coming back on another will generally cancel each other out and the wire runs between the motor controller and the motors themselves tend to be short (for brushless motors) and the CANbus normally ends at the motor controller anyway. But even though EMI is generally not a huge concern, it does not hurt to use twisted pairs.

If you are creating your own CANbus wire runs, I recommend twisting the yellow and green wires together. It is relatively easy to create a twisted pair by taking two equal length segments of wires (yellow and green), stretching them out side by side across a room (not tight). You hold one end of the pair of wires and then clamp the other end of that pair in the chuck of a drill and run the drill at relatively low speed to twist the wires together. You don’t need to have the wires twisted particularly tightly. Generally 1 to 2 twists per inch of length is plenty tight. Once the pair is twisted, you can wind the twisted pair onto a wire spool for storage and then cut it to different lengths when you need it.

posts.name: Zach Hoegberg
posts.cooked: In general use, i.e. industry, i.e. not FRC, it’s a best practice to keep low power signal conductors isolated from high power conductors because the current in the high power wires can induce a current in the low power wires large enough to cause issues with the signals being transmitted. There are multiple ways to mitigated this used in the real world. One of them is using differential signal twisted pair conductors, like CAN. The idea there is that the actual signal is read as a difference between a “high” and a “low” signal wire as opposed to something like PWM which is read between a “high” signal wire and a “universal” ground. The twisted wire pair means that if any current is induced in one wire in a pair, a very similar amount of current is induced in the other wire. This combined with the differential signaling means it is much more robust to this kind of issue, especially at the levels of current we typically see in FRC. As someone else alluded to, you can also shield the wires, which essentially creates a Faraday cage around the wires which helps to absorb and redirect some of the induced current to decrease the magnitude of change in the signal wires.
